content.description: Another one in the pit behind Seams Like Fun.
content.protection: Bring wide gear, or top-rope it.
content.location: The most obvious feature on the south wall of the pit.

content.description: Follow the left side of the Breaker face. The route is very height dependent, and the start is especially tricky if you're short. Fun, short, reachy climbing between horizontal cracks. Less crimpy than Circuit Breaker.
content.location: Start on the left side of the Breaker face.

content.description: I haven't climbed this one; including it for completeness sake.
content.protection: Unknown.  Gear only anchor.  Easy walk-off.
content.location: Approx 8 feet right of Circuit Breaker; climb obvious V-offwidth and seam above to top.

content.description: Short, sweet route at the right end of the Seams Like Fun area.  Worthwhile to lead, or TR off the tree at the top.  Goes over the obvious bulge.
content.protection: G rated.  You can even place the first nut from the ledge at the base.  A #3 Camalot is helpful.
content.location: Starts directly behind the largest black birch in that area.  Just before the wall ends at an arete.

content.description: A rather fun little line up the face located midway between the Seams Like Fun formation and the trail that leads to the top of the cliff.  Some finicky but solid small nut placements keep it to a G rating.
content.protection: Nuts and cams to one inch.  Trees up top for anchor.
content.location: If you're walking from the First Day Climb area towards the Breakfast wall, this is the first crag you come to after passing the trail to the top . Go up the center of the face past the obvious left-slanting crack halfway up.  Walk down.

content.description: Crux is halfway up (long reach).  Rather short route for the effort of leading it.
content.protection: G - the route follows a crack.  Gear only anchor at top.
content.location: Climb obvious thin seam in main face to top.  Walk off to the right.

content.description: A TR line up the face to a clean right-facing corner at the top, and then a testy mantle exit.
content.location: On the face 6 ft right of Seams Like Fun.

content.description:
Short route, one-move wonder, generally not occupied.  If you want to use the huge pine tree for an anchor point, please look at it more carefully - IT'S DEAD. 

  Crux is at the bottom.  Make sure your belayer is alert.
content.protection: Protection is barely adequate and requires creativity; I'd give this a "sporty" rating.
content.location: Climb right side of block up obvious seam; cleaner than its neighbor to the left.

content.description: Nasty, pebbly, not really worth climbing unless you're on a quest to climb every route here, or are some sort of masochist.
content.protection: Adequate, but barely.  Creativity needed to protect crux, but it's possible.
content.location: Climb left side of block up through flaring offwidth, to top. Walk off to the right.

content.description: Not a great route, but it's there.  Note that doing a standard slingshot belay is difficult; someone will need to belay from the top.
content.protection: Adequate.  Gear only anchor.  Beware of potential loose rock.
content.location: Behind the detached block containing Left Block, Right Block, and Seams Like Fun, there is a hole.  Climb the dihedral on the far left side, starting all the way down at the bottom.

content.description: I haven't climbed this one, including it for completeness sake.  I've heard people say that it's fun.
content.location: Climb face approx 8 feet left of obvious V-offwidth, and a few feet right of obvious tree at top of cliff.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: Climb the right edge of the face, topping out on slab leading left to trees.
content.location: Just right of Skeeter (5.5) at right edge of face.

content.description: In the "pit" (hole) behind the Seams Like Fun formation. The route is an arete that becomes a nice finger crack in a clean 90 degree dihedral.  It's too bad that it's so short.
content.protection: Gear looks OK but we only TR'ed it
content.location: Look for the obtuse (i.e. not sharp) arete that inverts to become a square dihedral at mid height.
